sub_title: Assistant Professor in the Department of Radiology at the University of Vermont | Founder and owner U-Ridge Health | Commissioner
summary:
Dr. van den Broek-Altenburg is Assistant Professor (tenure track) and Vice-Chair of Population Health Science in the Department of Radiology at the University of Vermont College of Medicine. She is also visiting at Amsterdam UMC and the American University of Armenia. She holds a PhD in Health Services Research (cognates in Economics, Biostatistics, Epidemiology) (2018),MSc in Public Health (2014) and MA in Political Science (2003). 

Her research deals with developing and empirically testing value assessment methods and involves the application of neuroeconomics and behavioral economics to understand health behaviors and treatment preferences, e.g. related to cancer, cardiovascular conditions and Alzheimer's. She uses discrete choice modelling to analyze patient and provider preferences in terms of their evaluation of alternative options and trade-offs they make. She is developing a blueprint for implementation of individual emotions, habits, biases, heuristics and environmental factors that affect individual preferences to inform patient decision support systems and integration in EHRs.

She recently received a grant to further explore non-compensatory decision making in seeking diagnostic imaging services. She also won a health disparities challenge award for a paper exploring methodological approaches to incorporating unobserved factors influencing preferences for Covid-19 vaccination. The study concluded that health care interventions that do not reflect the underlying values of individuals are unlikely to be successful. 

Dr. van den Broek-Altenburg also leads health economic evaluations of clinical interventions, using EHR, claims and text data. For the past two decades, she has collaborated with policy makers and clinicians to develop standardized quantitative measures and align the data infrastructure to assess health system performance.

Since the COVID-19 pandemic, she has contributed to a number of studies, including one identifying factors that may increase the risk of infection and the impact of the crisis on individuals, both in health, financial and psychological terms. She currently leads a study into the effect of Covid-19 policies on excess mortality among acute care patients with cardiovascular conditions.

Between 2003 and 2009, she was a health policy adviser in the Dutch and European Parliaments. In 2005, she founded a think tank in The Hague and served as its director until 2012 when she returned to academia. In 2020, she founded U-Ridge Health and has since served as Commissioner and advisor in various healthcare organizations.
